metadata.title: Hydrocephalus in Children
synonyms: water on the brain in children
anatomical location body part affected: Brain/ultimately the entire individual is affected
description: Hydrocephalus is a condition caused by an imbalance in the production and absorption of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the ventricular system. Hydrocephalus is defined as an abnormal accumulation of CSF in the ventricular system within the cranial vault that results in increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and passive dilation of the ventricles(1,8)

Types of hydrocephalus –Congenital(2,3) –Acquired(2,3) –Communicating – CSF is able to flow from ventricle to ventricle and circulate in its normal manner; however, there is impaired absorption, resulting in abnormal accumulation of CSF(3) –Noncommunicating–  occurs when the flow of CSF is blocked along one or more of the narrow pathways connecting the ventricles(2) -May be referred to as obstructive hydrocephalus(2)

Q03.Q03.1: atresia of foramina of Magendie and Luschka Dandy-Walker syndrome

ICD-10 codes.Q07.0: Arnold-Chiari syndrome (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: In an infant/toddler, signs and symptoms may include: –“Sunsetting” –described  as “a downward deviation of the eyes, and separation of the cranial sutures with a bulging anterior fontanelle”(1) –Bulging fontanelles (especially anterior) with or without head enlargement(2) -Fontanelles feel tense and nonpulsatile(2) –Pronounced/dilated scalp veins(6) –Abrupt change in head circumference(2,4,5) -Researchers of a retrospective study conducted in the Netherlands concluded that increases in head circumference were useful in diagnosing hydrocephalus only in the first year of life(20) –Macrocephaly(2,6) –Frontal bone bossing/enlargement(2) –A gap/separation between the coronal and sagittal sutures can be felt(4,6) –Thinning of skull bones(2) –Macewen sign: tapping of the skull near the junction of the frontal, temporal, and parietal bones produces a stronger, resonant “cracked-pot”  sound(2) –Irritability(2,4,6,(7) –Drowsiness(2)/lethargy(4,7) –V omiting(2,4,5,6) –Seizures(2,4,5) –Pupils sluggish with unequal response to light(2) –Trouble feeding(4,5) –Infant cries when picked up or rocked and quiets when at rest and still(2) –Piercing cry(4,5) –Resistance to repositioning the head/neck(5) –Developmental delay(5) –Lower extremity spasticity(2) –Persistent neonatal reflexes(2) –Opisthotonos(i.e., abnormal posturing in which the body is rigid, back is arched, and head is thrown backward) – often extreme(2)

In an older child, signs and symptoms may include: –Headaches coupled with vomiting(2,5,6) -Headache improves after vomiting or being in an upright posture(2) –Nausea(2,5) –Irritability(2,5,7) –Incontinence of bladder that begins or worsens(2,5) –Deterioration in school performance(4,5) –Neck pain(4) –Personality changes(2,4,5) –Incoherence(2) –Confusion(5) –Impaired memory(2,5) –Sunsetting of the eyes(2,5,6)  –Impaired vision(2,5) -Strabismus, papilledema(2) –Developmental delay or loss of acquired skills(2,5) -Impaired balance -Impaired gait -Impaired coordination –Onset of or increased spasticity(4) –Reduced energy level(2,5)/lethargy/apathy(2) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention during assessment

causes: the causes of hydrocephalus in: Developmental malformation–Most cases of noncommunicating hydrocephalus are a result of developmental malformations. Although the malformationis present in early infancy, the development of hydrocephalus may not become evident until late childhood or earlyadulthood(8)–Developmental defects account for most cases of hydrocephalus from birth to 2 years of age–In older children, hydrocephalus is most often a result of intracranial masses, intracranial infections, hemorrhage, ortrauma–Some of the most common developmental malformations are listed below-For more information on myelomeningocele, see Clinical Review…Spina Bifida ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708537-Dandy-Walker  malformation(7,8)-Arnold-Chiari  malformation(1,7)-Aqueduct stenosis, aqueduct gliosis(8)-Dysmorphic syndromes (e.g., Apert syndrome, trisomy 13, trisomy 21)(7)-Mucopolysaccharidosis (e.g., type II [Hunter])(7)-Migrational disorders/congenital muscular dystrophies (e.g., Miller-Dieker,  muscle-eye-brain disease)(7)-Achondroplasia(7)-Alexander disease(7)-Neurocutaneous syndromes (e.g., neurofibromatosis type 1)(7)

This Clinical Review focuses on childhood hydrocephalus. For information about the adult-onset  syndrome normalpressure hydrocephalus, please see Clinical Review …Hydrocephalus, Normal Pressure ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709056
pathogenesis: Hydrocephalus can occur when:–The absorption of CSF is reduced(7,8)–The circulation of CSF is obstructed(7,8)–CSF is produced in excess(7)

Pathophysiology of hydrocephalus(8)–There is an abnormal increase in CSF within the ventricles of the brain, causing the ventricles to dilate (ventriculomegaly)and compress the brain tissue against the rigid cranium. As a result, ICP rises–When this occurs prior to the cranial sutures fusing, the skull will enlarge and the ventricles dilate. In children underthe age of 12 years, who have partially closed suture lines, especially the sagittal suture, the suture can open or partiallyseparate–An obstruction to the normal CSF flow can occur at any point in the CSF pathway and will result in a rise in ICP anddilation of the pathways proximal to the site of obstruction(8)

Myelomeningocele(1)–When Arnold-Chiari  malformation is present in an infant, the cerebellum, medulla, and cervical spinal cord are impacted–The malformation impedes the circulation of CSF–The vast majority of infants with Arnold-Chiari  malformation will develop hydrocephalus
risk factors: Prematurity(5)–In a study conducted in Germany, researchers found that ventricular size on cranial ultrasonography in preterm and terminfants was not only correlated to gestational age, but also to birthweight(25)
Infections affecting the brain and spinal cord(5)

Genetic factors(10)–The presence of adducted thumbs and aqueductal stenosis is suggestive of X-linked  hydrocephalus due to neural celladhesion moleculeL1 deficiency(10)–Rhombencephalosynapsis is a rare genetic abnormality that is associated with hydrocephalus and aqueductal stenosis. It ishypothesized that a defect involving common gene(s) may be responsible

Being a first-born  child or first trimester maternal use of antidepressants for idiopathic hydrocephalus(21)–Based on a cohort of 1,928,666 live-born  children in Denmark (between 1978 and 2008), of whom 1,193 had idiopathichydrocephalus–The researchers also determined that male sex, multiple births, and maternal diabetes were risk factors for hydrocephalusassociated with congenital malformation (n = 985 children)

overall contraindications precautions: Following shunt placement in an infant Individual physicians and hospitals have their own specific protocols regarding physical therapy intervention following shunt placement. The severity of hydrocephalus prior to shunt placement is carefully considered by the physician as he or she determines when physical therapy may begin. At a minimum, physical therapy intervention can begin 24 to 48 hours following surgery(1) The severity of hydrocephalus prior to shunt placement will affect the timing of when the child may receive oral feedings, position changes, ROM exercises, and handling in the upright position. If such interventions begin too early, a significant decrease in ICP can develop and vascular insult can occur(1)

Shunt complications include: Obstruction(4,7) –Original symptoms return(6) Infection(4,7) Mechanical failure(2,7)  Catheter fracture(27) –The presence of shunt calcifications increases risk for shunt fracture System requires lengthening(2) Overdraining(2,7) –Siphoning(7) -When the forces of gravity (patient in sit or stand) cause more CSF to exit the ventricles than desired -Symptoms -Headaches -Nausea -V omiting -Shunts now have specific components that are included to avert this phenomenon Underdraining(2) –Symptoms of hydrocephalus persist in spite of shunt placement(6)
Shunt complications are extremely serious; if proper medical care is not obtained, coma and/or death can occur(6)
Symptoms of shunt complications may include: Return of original symptoms(7) Fever(6) Swelling adjacent to the pathway of the shunt(6) Erythema adjacent to the pathway of the shunt(6)

Clinicians must be aware that the valve components of shunts can be impacted by magnetic fields (e.g., MRI, vagus nerve stimulator magnets); depending on strength, magnetic fields can cause changes in the set drainage pressure that can be dangerous to the patient

Abrupt occlusion of the endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) can occur(6) For a description of this procedure, see Medical management , below This occurrence is also extremely serious, as death may result if prompt medical management is not obtained If a patient experiences an abrupt sealing off of the ETV , generally the original symptoms return
Follow facility protocols for obtaining parental consent
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What type of hydrocephalus has been diagnosed? How old was the child when it was diagnosed? What were the child’s symptoms? Was the child premature?Were there complications during pregnancy or delivery? What is the current reason for referral?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Hydrocephalus is most often treated surgically by inserting a shunt system. The system is designed to divert the flow of CSF from the CNS to another area of the body where it can be absorbed as part of the normal circulatory process.(2) The surgical approach may be described as posterior or frontal, referring to the area of the brain the proximal catheter must pass to reach the ventricles A shunt system is composed of a shunt (flexible tube), ventricular catheter, flush pump, valve, and distal catheter. The valve, located along the catheter, maintains a oneway  flow and regulates the rate of CSF flow. The valves are designed to open at a predetermined intraventricular pressure and close when the pressure falls below that level, preventing fluid backflow(2)  Shunt typesan internal shunt that transports excess CSF from one lateral ventricle to the right atrium. Due to increased risk of septicemia, ventriculitis, superior vena cava occlusion, and pulmonary emboli, the V A shunt is not used as commonly as others(1)an internal shunt that transports excess CSF from the lateral ventricle directly into the peritoneum, where it can be reabsorbed and the excess excreted. It is the preferred method for shunt placement. There is a greater risk for shunt occlusion; however, the complications are much less severe compared to a V A shunt(1)an internal shunt that transports excess CSF from the subarachnoid space to the peritoneum. Typically used for patients who have a pathology that obstructs CSF flow. The advantages compared to VP or V A shunts are the avoidance of brain penetrance, large CSF space in the thecal sac, and potential for large amount of CSF drainage.(16) It is more commonly used for adults but may be used in children as an alternative to a VP shunt for the management of communicating hydrocephalus(16) In a 2019 retrospective study conducted in Taiwan, researchers concluded there was a lower complication rate associated with LP shunt compared to VP shunt (1% and 13.5%, respectively). The overall revision rate due to shunt malfunction was 7.3% in both groups(16) A reservoir placement may be appropriate to siphon excess CSF for a period of time into a superficial well that can be emptied by needle aspiration. Reservoir placements may be used to assess the need for a shunt and the specific type of shunt that would be best suited for a child(1) External shunt placement  common in inpatient settings following surgery or during treatment of a shunt infection Please see  Overall Contraindications/Precautions  , above, for shunt complications ETV  alternative procedure to a shunt system for managing hydrocephalus(2) A tiny opening is surgically created in the floor of the 3rd ventricle with the use of a neuroendoscope, allowing CSF to bypass the obstruction and recirculate toward the site of reabsorption around the brain’s surface(2) ETV  indications(9) The ideal patient for this procedure has a diagnosis of noncommunicating hydrocephalus with the obstruction located at the aqueduct of Sylvius ETV may be appropriate for other patients, including those with spina bifida or Arnold-Chiari malformation; however, this decision must be carefully weighed by the physician and depends on unique patient circumstances Children presenting with shunt malfunction may be better served with ETV instead of shunt revision When ETV was first introduced, it was considered, in contrast to shunts, to be minimally invasive and effective for treating hydrocephalus. It is now recognized that serious complications can also occur after ETV(15) ETV  precautions/potential contraindications to procedure(9) History of interventricular hemorrhage History of subarachnoid hemorrhage History of infection affecting the brain and/or spinal cord Infants ETV  potential complications of procedure(9) Death Basilar artery injury Neurological insult Intraventricular hemorrhage Subdural hematoma Infection Following the postsurgical phase, occlusion may occur and death can result Endoscopic aqueductal stenting (EAS)  an alternative shunting procedure to address aqueductal stenosis has been shown to greatly reduce the number of shuntrelated  surgeries required in children with hydrocephalus (15) Results of a 2014 systematic review conducted by the Pediatric Hydrocephalus Systematic Review and EvidenceBased  Guidelines Task Force indicate that both shunts and ETV demonstrated equivalent outcomes in the clinical etiologies studies(22)  Based on the results of a 2020 updated systematic review of the 2014 Evidence-Based Guidelines on the treatment of(28) Neuroendoscopic lavage was found to be a safe option for removal of intraventricular clots Use of antibiotic-impregnated  shunt tubing compared to conventional silicone hardware reduces risk of shunt infection
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Hydrocephalus can be diagnosed by head circumference measurements. A head circumference measurement that crosses at least one percentile line on the head measurement chart within 2 to 4 weeks, may be indicative of hydrocephalus. Adapted head circumference charts for preterm infants are used to differentiate between abnormal head growth and typical rapid head growth(17)
Prenatal ultrasounds can reveal the presence of hydrocephalus(6)
In neonates, echoencephalography can be used to compare the ratio of lateral ventricle to cortex(2)
The primary diagnostic tools for toddlers and other children are CT scans and MRI(10)

Fast-sequence  MRI (taking approximately 3.37 minutes) is being used with non-sedated  children to limit radiation and anesthesia exposure and limit artifacts from movement, and has been shown to have excellent overall quality and a high degree of interrater reliability(23)
Ultrasound of the head may be used in newborns(7)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there any reported aggravating or easing factors?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms where indicated
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use FLACC, a visual analog scale (V AS), or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., confusion,(5) irritability(2,5))
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise? Has the patient ever required intubation or supplemental oxygen? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Does the patient have a history significant for meningitis?(2) tumors?(2) intraventricular cysts?(6) TBI?(2) subarachnoid hemorrhage?(2) intraventricular hemorrhage?(7)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient/caregiver about other problems and associated conditions, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Associated conditions may include other congenital abnormalities, other CNS pathologies, and seizures
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient/caregiver about other symptoms the patient may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational activities? Does the patient go to school?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any reported limitations in ADLs. Document achievement and/or loss of developmental milestones up to this point
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Is the family supportive and understanding of the child’s condition? Are social and community supports available and accessible?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  The information presented below is meant to serve as a guide. Clinicians are advised to modify/supplement the examination process as indicated by the patient’s age and unique circumstances
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Clinician should refer to physician’s reports on patient’s head circumference measurements. Clinician can also measure patient’s head circumference –Measure height and weight and compare to age- and sex-matched growth curves -Children with shunts often have smaller head circumferences as they age compared to children without a shunt(18) -In a study conducted in Sweden that included 50 children with shunt placement before they were 12 months of age who were compared to age- and sex-matched  normative data over a 4-year  period, researchers concluded that the predictors for low head circumference are low weight, decreased height for age, and frequent shunt valve revisions(18) -Hydrocephalus can cause feeding problems, nausea, and vomiting -Nutritional issues and delayed growth and weight gain are common in conditions that are associated with hydrocephalus -Obesity may be a problem in children with myelomeningocele due to mobility limitations and decreased energy expenditure(4)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient utilize any assistive or adaptive devices? If so, are they appropriate?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance using the Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS), the balance subscale of the Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2),  or the Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2).  Ataxia may be present
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: In advanced acute hydrocephalus, Cushing triad (hypertension, reflex bradycardia, respiratory irregularities) can be seen after fusion of head sutures(7) •Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity:  Assess the cranial nerves as indicated; cranial nerves that assist with vision may be impacted.(7) Observe for dilated pupils indicating increased ICP due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on the ipsilateral side of increased pressure.(8) Refer to an appropriate specialist as indicated •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.): Complete a functional assessment using the WeeFIM
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Complete a gait assessment in the ambulatory child. Note asymmetry of movement, gait speed, stride and step length, or arm swing –In the ambulatory child with chronic hydrocephalus, ataxia may be noted during gait(7) Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity joint integrity as indicated by symptoms and patient presentation. Use Paris Stoddard Scale for joint mobility Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Evaluate muscle tone and motor control as indicated. Document any hypotonia or hypertonicity. Use the Modified Ashworth Scale to measure spasticity. Document whether the child is able to isolate individual muscle groups against gravity or if the child uses synergistic patterns -In the child with chronic hydrocephalus, hypertonicity may be present in the extremities(7) –Evaluate child’s upper and lower extremity coordination, assessing for dysmetria or dysdiadochokinesia
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Complete a thorough strength assessment using manual muscle testing if there are no tone or coordination issues. In younger children a functional assessment of strength may be necessary depending on ability to follow instructions. The strength subscale of the BOT-2can  be used for children older than 5 years. Assess pinch and grip strength using a pinch gauge and handheld dynamometerUtilize standardized tests to assess neuromotor development (e.g., PDMS-2,BOT-2,  Alberta Infant Motor Scales [AIMS])
observation inspection palpation includi: Impaired motion processing, vision problems, and poor coordination may be present in children with hydrocephalus (13)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess the patient’s sitting and standing posture. Assess posture of an infant or toddler in supine and prone. Note any asymmetry or abnormal posturing movements
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Evaluate bilateral upper and lower extremity passive and active ROM. Assess active and passive cervical ROM. Observe active ROM with functional activities
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity deep tendon reflexes; a child with hydrocephalus may present with hyperreflexia(7)Assess ADLs and note impairments
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Complete bilateral upper and lower extremity sensory testing for light touch and pinprick as indicated and appropriate. Assess upper and lower extremity joint proprioception
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: The Hydrocephalus Outcome Questionnaire (HOQ) can be used to assess physical, mental, social, emotional, and cognitive status.(11)Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory QL, 4th edition, Short Form-15 (PedsQL) can be used
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess the patient’s arousal level and complete a cognitive assessment as indicated. Is the patient alert and oriented x 4? Is the patient able to attend and focus on a task? Can the patient follow simple and multiple-step  commands? –Irritability or somnolence in infants can be seen as well as behavioral changes in children in both acute and chronic conditions(7)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Movement of the child into a Trendelenburg position(i.e., supine with feet elevated 15° to 30° higher than the head) is contraindicated, as this may disrupt the appropriate drainage of the CSF from the cranial vault

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Physical therapy typically begins 1 to 2 days after shunt placement in an infant; however, physician orders must be obtained because initiating intervention too early can harm the infant.(1) Please see  Overall Contraindications/ Precautions  , above, for more details
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out The physician should rule out alternative causes of macrocephaly (e.g., familial macrocephaly) and ventriculomegaly(7)  Benign external hydrocephalus(7)
prognosis: Generally, without proper medical management, hydrocephalus (which is progressive in nature) is fatal(2)

The Hydrocephalus Clinical Research Network (HCRN) comprises 14 children’s hospitals in North America that conduct research and provide multicenter assessments of outcomes of CSF shunting and other surgical interventions. In 2018 researchers conducted a prospective study of the surgical procedures ETV and choroid plexus cauterization (CPC) in infants and compared the data to a historical cohort of infants treated with shunt or ETV alone(19) –Using data from 2014–2015  researchers compared outcomes for infants undergoing either a shunt (n = 969) or EVT alone (n = 74) with infants who underwent ETV + CPC (n = 118), resulting in 112 matched pairs for ETV + CPC versus shunt alone and 34 matched pairs for ETV + CPC versus ETV alone –Mean age of patients in the HCRN cohort was 1.3 months –The most common etiologies were myelomeningocele, intraventricular hemorrhage, and aqueductal stenosis –Complications included seizures, CSF leak –Data showed a significantly greater failure rate in the ETV + CPC group compared to shunt alone, but a similar failure rate when compared to ETV-alone  group ›Researchers in Germany who conducted a 2018 retrospective analysis of pediatric hydrocephalus shunt independence found that independence was achieved in approximately 3–9%  of patients (29)
212 pediatric patients enrolled in 29 separate independence trials who received shunts between 2000 and 2016 were included in the study and followed for one year post surgery

Researchers found that secondary EVT surgery at the time of shunt failure had the highest success rate (75%) in achieving independence and that the removal of the shunt due to overdrainage increased likelihood of shunt failure ›In a similar study conducted in India in 2018, researchers evaluated the clinical outcomes of shunt surgeries in children with hydrocephalus and risk factors for VP shunt failure(30)
A total of 137 patients with the average age of 20.7 months (range 1.5 months to 8.5 years) post VP shunt placement were included in the study
Overall shunt complication rate was about 36%
Incidence of shunt revision was 27% and blockage 46%
Risk factors associated with shunt failure included hydrocephalus associated with post-tubercular  meningitis and intraventricular hemorrhage
Cognitive impairments and difficulties in school affect 10–50%  of children with hydrocephalus (12)

The prognosis is variable based on the following:(2) –Underlying cause –Comorbid conditions –Length of time between onset of symptoms and time of diagnosis –Treatment outcomes (e.g., response to shunting)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Neurologist Occupational therapist (OT) Speech-language  pathologist (SLP) Psychologist Social services Ophthalmologist – strabismus is frequently observed with hydrocephalus(4)
other considerations: Extremely preterm infants (< 28 weeks) with a low concentration of corticotropin-releasing  hormonemessenger ribonucleic acid (CRH mRNA) in the placenta are at increased risk of ventriculomegaly on ultrasound scan, whereas an elevated concentration of CRH mRNA is associated with increased risk of an inability to walk at the age of 2 years and a Bayley Motor Scale 3 standard deviations below the mean(26)
treatment summary: No studies evaluating the efficacy of rehabilitation interventions for this condition were identified  . maintenance or prevention: With normal growth, the tubing can be pulled out or disconnected from the distal insertion site. Parents need to be constantly aware of the signs and symptoms associated with shunt failure(2) There is a need for professionals and parents to collaborate when assessing a child with potential shunt malfunction  –Results from a study conducted in the United States indicate that parents of children with hydrocephalus perceived that their expertise was not always valued by professionals and not used to inform decisions about care(24) -The author noted the need for better integration of parents’ input into assessment and treatment

Patients with shunts have special lifelong healthcare needs. They should be monitored and evaluated on a regular basis by their healthcare providers.(2) Patients and primary caregivers need to be educated on the necessity of regular checkups (by a physician trained in the management of hydrocephalus) for the continued monitoring of their condition(12)
Patients should also be reminded that shunt complications can arise at any time (even years after implantation)(12)
Active children may fall and have injuries that can damage the shunt. Contact sports should be avoided(2)
Prenatal folic acid is associated with reduced incidence of neural tube defects
Antenatal ultrasound screening may detect neural tube defects and hydrocephalus
Recent evidence supports Prenatal repair of myelomeningocele to reduce risk of developing shunt-dependent  hydrocephalus (31)
patient education: Based on results of a 2017 utilization survey of 3 social media platforms, parents and caregivers of children with hydrocephalus frequently use social media networking for support and information gathering(14)
